A MAC Address is a globally unique identifier for a device. As a Computer Science student, you should be able to figure out a device\'s MAC Address. Here are a few examples on how to do so: Android Phone or Tablet https://kb.iu.edu/d/bbis Mac OS X https://www.iclarified.com/30929/how-to-find-your-mac-address-in-mac-os-x A TP-Link Router https://www.tp-link.com/us/faq-126.html
As a first step you can try to find a list of connected devices along with MAC Addresses on your router\'s homepage. For example, here is how you do it for a NETGEAR router: https://www.wikihow.com/See-Who-Is-Connected-to-Your-Wireless-Network
You can also individually check the devices in your home for their MAC Address.
Try the gateway homepage

Data Collection The application is going to collect the following data for the network you are currently on: Information on the connected devices like vendor, device model, hashed MAC Address, IP address. A list of open ports and servers running — along with the vulnerabilities they have — on the connected devices. The public IP of the network. Device names as they help us identify the type of device (for example, Wajeeha’s Ipad). You can choose to opt out of this if you want to.
